name: D20 Tests
description:
When the outcome of an action is uncertain, the game uses a d20 roll to determine success or failure. These rolls are called D20 Tests, and they come in three kinds: ability checks, saving throws, and attack rolls. They follow these steps:

1. **Roll 1d20.** You always want to roll high. If the roll has Advantage or Disadvantage, you roll two d20s, but you use the number from only one of them - the higher one if you have Advantage or the lower one if you have Disadvantage.

2. **Add Modifiers.** Add these modifiers to the number rolled on the d20:
   - The Relevant Ability Modifier
   - Your Proficiency Bonus If Relevant
   - Circumstantial Bonuses and Penalties

3. **Compare the Total to a Target Number.** If the total of the d20 and its modifiers equals or exceeds the target number, the D20 Test succeeds. Otherwise, it fails. The target number for an ability check or a saving throw is called a Difficulty Class (DC). The target number for an attack roll is called an Armor Class (AC).

## Ability Checks

An ability check represents a creature using talent and training to try to overcome a challenge, such as forcing open a stuck door, picking a lock, entertaining a crowd, or deciphering a cipher.

### Ability Check Examples

| Ability | Make a Check To... |
|---------|-------------------|
| Strength | Lift, push, pull or break something |
| Dexterity | Move nimbly, quickly, or quietly |
| Constitution | Push your body beyond normal limits |
| Intelligence | Reason or remember |
| Wisdom | Notice things in the environment or in creatures' behavior |
| Charisma | Influence, entertain, or deceive |

### Typical Difficulty Classes

| Task Difficulty | DC |
|-----------------|-----|
| Very easy | 5 |
| Easy | 10 |
| Medium | 15 |
| Hard | 20 |
| Very hard | 25 |
| Nearly impossible | 30 |

## Saving Throws

A saving throw represents an attempt to evade or resist a threat, such as a fiery explosion, a blast of poisonous gas, or a spell trying to invade your mind. You don't normally choose to make a save; you must make one because your character is at risk.

### Saving Throw Examples

| Ability | Make a Save To... |
|---------|-------------------|
| Strength | Physically resist direct force |
| Dexterity | Dodge out of harm's way |
| Constitution | Endure a toxic hazard |
| Intelligence | Recognize an illusion as fake |
| Wisdom | Resist a mental assault |
| Charisma | Assert your identity |

## Attack Rolls

An attack roll determines whether an attack hits a target. An attack roll hits if the roll equals or exceeds the target's Armor Class.

### Attack Roll Abilities

| Ability | Attack Type |
|---------|------------|
| Strength | Melee attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike |
| Dexterity | Ranged attack with a weapon |
| Varies | Spell attack (determined by the spellcaster's spellcasting feature) |

### Rolling 20 or 1

If you roll a 20 on the d20 (a "natural 20") for an attack roll, the attack hits regardless of any modifiers or the target's AC. This is called a Critical Hit. If you roll a 1 (a "natural 1"), the attack misses regardless of any modifiers or the target's AC.

## Advantage and Disadvantage

Advantage reflects positive circumstances surrounding a d20 roll, while Disadvantage reflects negative circumstances.

**Roll Two D20s:** When a roll has either Advantage or Disadvantage, roll a second d20 when you make the roll. Use the higher of the two rolls if you have Advantage, and use the lower roll if you have Disadvantage.

**They Don't Stack:** If multiple situations affect a roll and they all grant Advantage, you still roll only two d20s. Similarly, if multiple situations impose Disadvantage, you roll only two d20s. If circumstances cause a roll to have both Advantage and Disadvantage, the roll has neither of them, and you roll one d20.

### Heroic Inspiration

If you have Heroic Inspiration, you can expend it to reroll any die immediately after rolling it, and you must use the new roll. You can never have more than one instance of Heroic Inspiration.

name: Exploration
description:
Exploration involves delving into places that are dangerous and full of mystery. The rules in this section detail some of the ways adventurers interact with the environment in such places.

## Adventuring Equipment

As adventurers explore, their equipment can help them in many ways. For example, they can reach out-of-the-way places with a Ladder, perceive things they wouldn't otherwise notice with a Torch or another light source, bypass locked doors and containers with Thieves' Tools, and create obstacles for pursuers with Caltrops.

## Vision and Light

Some adventuring tasks - such as noticing danger, hitting an enemy, and targeting certain spells - are affected by sight, so effects that obscure vision can hinder you.

### Obscured Areas

An area might be Lightly or Heavily Obscured. In a Lightly Obscured area - such as an area with Dim Light, patchy fog, or moderate foliage - you have Disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

A Heavily Obscured area - such as an area with Darkness, heavy fog, or dense foliage - is opaque. You have the Blinded condition when trying to see something there.

### Light Levels

**Bright Light.** Bright Light lets most creatures see normally. Even gloomy days provide Bright Light, as do torches, lanterns, fires, and other sources of illumination within a specific radius.

**Dim Light.** Dim Light, also called shadows, creates a Lightly Obscured area. An area of Dim Light is usually a boundary between Bright Light and surrounding Darkness. The soft light of twilight and dawn also counts as Dim Light.

**Darkness.** Darkness creates a Heavily Obscured area. Characters face Darkness outdoors at night (even most moonlit nights), within the confines of an unlit dungeon, or in an area of magical Darkness.

### Special Senses

Some creatures have special senses that help them perceive things in certain situations:
- Blindsight
- Darkvision
- Tremorsense
- Truesight

## Hiding

Adventurers and monsters often hide, whether to spy on one another, sneak past a guardian, or set an ambush. The Game Master decides when circumstances are appropriate for hiding. When you try to hide, you take the Hide action.

## Interacting with Objects

Interacting with objects is often simple to resolve. The player tells the GM that their character is doing something, such as moving a lever or opening a door, and the GM describes what happens.

### Time-Limited Object Interactions

When time is short, such as in combat, interactions with objects are limited: one free interaction per turn. That interaction must occur during a creature's movement or action. Any additional interactions require the Utilize action.

## Travel

During an adventure, the characters might travel long distances on trips that could take hours or days. The GM can summarize this travel without calculating exact distances or travel times, or the GM might have you use the travel pace rules below.

### Travel Pace Table

| Pace | Distance Per Minute | Per Hour | Per Day |
|------|---------------------|----------|--------|
| Fast | 400 feet | 4 miles | 30 miles |
| Normal | 300 feet | 3 miles | 24 miles |
| Slow | 200 feet | 2 miles | 18 miles |

**Fast.** Traveling at a Fast pace imposes Disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception or Survival) and Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

**Normal.** Traveling at a Normal pace imposes Disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

**Slow.** Traveling at a Slow pace grants Advantage on Wisdom (Perception or Survival) checks.

name: Combat
description:
Adventurers encounter many dangerous monsters and nefarious villains. In those moments, combat often breaks out.

## The Order of Combat

A typical combat encounter is a clash between two sides: a flurry of weapon swings, feints, parries, footwork, and spellcasting. The game organizes combat into a cycle of rounds and turns. A round represents about 6 seconds in the game world. During a round, each participant in a battle takes a turn. The order of turns is determined at the beginning of combat when everyone rolls Initiative. Once everyone has taken a turn, the fight continues to the next round if neither side is defeated.

### Combat Step by Step

1. **Establish Positions.** The Game Master determines where all the characters and monsters are located.
2. **Roll Initiative.** Everyone involved in the combat encounter rolls Initiative, determining the order of combatants' turns.
3. **Take Turns.** Each participant in the battle takes a turn in Initiative order. When everyone involved in the combat has had a turn, the round ends. Repeat this step until the fighting stops.

### Initiative

Initiative determines the order of turns during combat. When combat starts, every participant rolls Initiative; they make a Dexterity check that determines their place in the Initiative order. The GM rolls for monsters.

**Surprise.** If a combatant is surprised by combat starting, that combatant has Disadvantage on their Initiative roll.

### Your Turn

On your turn, you can move a distance up to your Speed and take one action. You decide whether to move first or take your action first.

**Communicating.** You can communicate however you are able - through brief utterances and gestures - as you take your turn. Doing so uses neither your action nor your move.

**Interacting with Things.** You can interact with one object or feature of the environment for free, during either your move or action.

## Movement and Position

On your turn, you can move a distance equal to your Speed or less. Or you can decide not to move.

### Playing on a Grid

**Squares.** Each square represents 5 feet.

**Speed.** Rather than moving foot by foot, move square by square on the grid, using your Speed in 5-foot segments.

### Creature Size and Space

| Size | Space (Feet) | Space (Squares) |
|------|--------------|----------------|
| Tiny | 2.5 by 2.5 feet | 4 per square |
| Small | 5 by 5 feet | 1 square |
| Medium | 5 by 5 feet | 1 square |
| Large | 10 by 10 feet | 4 squares (2 by 2) |
| Huge | 15 by 15 feet | 9 squares (3 by 3) |
| Gargantuan | 20 by 20 feet | 16 squares (4 by 4) |

### Difficult Terrain

Every foot of movement in Difficult Terrain costs 1 extra foot, even if multiple things in a space count as Difficult Terrain.

## Making an Attack

When you take the Attack action, you make an attack. Some other actions, Bonus Actions, and Reactions also let you make an attack.

1. **Choose a Target.** Pick a target within your attack's range: a creature, an object, or a location.
2. **Determine Modifiers.** The GM determines whether the target has Cover and whether you have Advantage or Disadvantage against the target.
3. **Resolve the Attack.** Make the attack roll. On a hit, you roll damage.

## Cover

| Degree | Benefit to Target | Offered By... |
|--------|------------------|---------------|
| Half | +2 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws | Another creature or an object that covers at least half of the target |
| Three-Quarters | +5 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws | An object that covers at least three-quarters of the target |
| Total | Can't be targeted directly | An object that covers the whole target |

## Opportunity Attacks

Combatants watch for enemies to drop their guard. If you move heedlessly past your foes, you put yourself in danger by provoking an Opportunity Attack.

**Avoiding Opportunity Attacks.** You can avoid provoking an Opportunity Attack by taking the Disengage action. You also don't provoke an Opportunity Attack when you Teleport or when you are moved without using your movement, action, Bonus Action, or Reaction.

**Making an Opportunity Attack.** You can make an Opportunity Attack when a creature that you can see leaves your reach. To make the attack, take a Reaction to make one melee attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike against that creature.

name: Damage and Healing
description:
## Hit Points

Hit Points represent durability and the will to live. Creatures with more Hit Points are more difficult to kill. Your maximum is your uninjured amount, ranging down to 0. Damage reduces your current Hit Points until reaching zero.

When your Hit Points drop to half or lower, you become Bloodied, which may trigger certain effects but has no inherent mechanical consequence.

## Damage Rolls

Each weapon, spell, and monster ability specifies damage dealt. Roll damage dice, add modifiers, and apply to the target. Penalties cannot result in negative damage - minimum is 0.

When attacking with a weapon, add the same ability modifier used for the attack roll. Spells specify which dice and modifiers apply.

## Critical Hits

On a Critical Hit, roll all damage dice twice, combine them, then add modifiers normally. For example, a Critical Hit with a Dagger deals 2d4 plus your modifier instead of 1d4. Additional damage dice from features (like Sneak Attack) also roll twice.

## Damage Types

Each damage instance has a type (Fire, Slashing, etc.). Types have no inherent mechanics but interact with Resistance, Vulnerability, and related rules.

## Resistance and Vulnerability

Creatures with Resistance to a damage type take half that damage (rounded down). Those with Vulnerability take double. Multiple instances of the same Resistance or Vulnerability count as one.

### Order of Application

1. Apply adjustments (bonuses, penalties, multipliers)
2. Apply Resistance
3. Apply Vulnerability

## Immunity

Immunity to a damage type means taking no damage of that type. Immunity to conditions means not being affected by them.

## Healing

Hit Points can be restored by magic, such as the Cure Wounds spell or a Potion of Healing, or by a Short or Long Rest. When healed, add restored points to current Hit Points, capped at your maximum.

## Dropping to 0 Hit Points

### Instant Death

**Monster Death:** Monsters die immediately upon reaching 0 Hit Points (GMs may override this).

**Hit Point Maximum of 0:** Creatures die if their maximum becomes 0.

**Massive Damage:** If damage reduces a character to 0 Hit Points with remaining damage equaling or exceeding their maximum, the character dies.

### Falling Unconscious

Reaching 0 Hit Points without instant death causes the Unconscious condition. You then make Death Saving Throws.

### Death Saving Throws

Starting your turn at 0 Hit Points requires a Death Saving Throw (DC 10, roll 1d20). Three successes stabilize you; three failures mean death. Track both separately.

Rolling a 1 counts as two failures. Rolling a 20 restores 1 Hit Point. Taking damage while at 0 Hit Points causes a failure (two if critical). Damage equaling or exceeding your maximum causes instant death.

### Stabilizing a Character

Use the Help action and succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check to stabilize someone at 0 Hit Points. Stable creatures don't make Death Saves but remain Unconscious. Taking damage resumes saves. Unhealed Stable creatures regain 1 Hit Point after 1d4 hours.

## Temporary Hit Points

Temporary Hit Points serve as damage absorption before actual Hit Points are affected.

**Lose Temporary Hit Points First:** Temporary points deplete before actual Hit Points. Overflow carries to actual Hit Points.

**Duration:** Temporary Hit Points last until depleted or you finish a Long Rest.

**They Don't Stack:** You cannot combine multiple sources. Choose to keep existing points or gain new ones instead.

**They're Not Hit Points or Healing:** Temporary Hit Points can't be added to your Hit Points, healing can't restore them, and receiving Temporary Hit Points doesn't count as healing. At 0 Hit Points, only true healing restores consciousness.

name: Spellcasting
description:
Spellcasting is a fundamental part of D&D, enabling characters to perform magical feats. This section covers the rules for gaining, preparing, and casting spells.

## Gaining Spells

Before casting a spell, you must have it prepared mentally or access it via magic items like Spell Scrolls. Your class features specify which spells you can access and how preparation works.

### Preparing Spells

If your class has preparable spells, the timing and quantity depend on your class:

| Class | Change When | Number |
|-------|------------|--------|
| Bard | Gain level | One |
| Cleric | Long Rest | Any |
| Druid | Long Rest | Any |
| Paladin | Long Rest | One |
| Ranger | Long Rest | One |
| Sorcerer | Gain level | One |
| Warlock | Gain level | One |
| Wizard | Long Rest | Any |

**Always-Prepared Spells.** Certain features grant spells you always have prepared, which don't count toward your preparation limit.

## Casting Spells

### Casting in Armor

You must have training with any armor you are wearing to cast spells while wearing it. If you lack proficiency with the armor you're wearing, you cannot cast spells.

### Spell Levels

Spells range from level 0 to level 9, indicating their power level. Cantrips—simple spells that can be cast almost by rote—are level 0.

### Spell Slots

When you cast a spell of level 1 or higher, you expend a slot of that spell's level or higher. Spell slots are restored after a Long Rest (or Short Rest for some classes like Warlocks).

### Casting Without Slots

**Cantrips.** Level 0 spells can be cast at will without expending spell slots.

**Rituals.** Spells with the Ritual tag can be cast in a ritual version that takes 10 minutes longer but doesn't expend a spell slot.

**Special Abilities.** Some class features and feats allow you to cast certain spells without expending a slot, typically once per Long Rest.

**Magic Items.** Spell Scrolls and other magic items may allow you to cast spells without using your own spell slots.

### Using Higher-Level Spell Slots

When a spellcaster casts a spell using a slot that is of a higher level than the spell, the spell takes on the higher level for that casting. Some spells have more powerful effects when cast at higher levels, as detailed in the spell's description.

### One Spell Slot Per Turn

On a turn, you can expend only one spell slot to cast a spell. This means if you cast a spell as a Bonus Action, any other spell you cast on that turn must be a cantrip with a casting time of one action.

### Schools of Magic

Eight schools categorize spells by their effect type:
- **Abjuration:** Protective spells
- **Conjuration:** Transporting objects and creatures
- **Divination:** Revealing information
- **Enchantment:** Affecting minds
- **Evocation:** Channeling energy for damage or healing
- **Illusion:** Deceiving the senses
- **Necromancy:** Manipulating life force
- **Transmutation:** Changing properties

## Casting Time

Most spells require one action to cast using the Magic action. Some spells use a Bonus Action, a Reaction, or take 1 minute or longer.

### Longer Casting Times

Spells requiring 1 minute or longer demand the Magic action each turn and maintained Concentration. If your Concentration is broken, the spell fails but you don't lose the spell slot.

## Range

Spells have ranges expressed as a distance in feet, Touch, or Self. Once a spell is cast, its effects aren't limited by range unless the spell description says otherwise.

## Components

Spells may require Verbal (V), Somatic (S), or Material (M) components.

**Verbal (V).** Casting requires speaking mystic words. Being silenced prevents spells with V components.

**Somatic (S).** Casting requires hand gestures. You must have a free hand or be holding your spellcasting focus.

**Material (M).** Casting requires specific items. A Component Pouch or Spellcasting Focus can substitute for most material components (unless the component has a listed cost or is consumed).

## Duration and Concentration

**Instantaneous.** The spell's magic vanishes immediately after casting.

**Concentration.** The spell requires ongoing focus. You can end Concentration at any time. Concentration breaks if you cast another Concentration spell, become Incapacitated, or fail a Constitution saving throw after taking damage (DC 10 or half the damage, whichever is higher).

**Time Span.** Some spells last for a specific duration and can be dismissed without an action if you're not Incapacitated.

## Targets and Areas of Effect

### Targets

Casters select targets the spell affects. To target something with a spell, you must have a clear path to it.

**Targeting Yourself.** You're a valid target for most spells unless the spell requires a hostile creature.

**Invalid Targets.** If a target is invalid (like targeting a creature immune to the spell), the spell slot is expended but the spell has no effect.

### Areas of Effect

Spells may affect areas rather than specific targets:
- **Cone:** Extends in a direction from the point of origin
- **Cube:** Fixed size from a point of origin
- **Cylinder:** Circular base with a height
- **Emanation:** Extends outward from a creature
- **Line:** Extends in a direction with a fixed width
- **Sphere:** Extends from a central point

## Saving Throws and Attack Rolls

**Spell Save DC** = 8 + your spellcasting ability modifier + your Proficiency Bonus

**Spell Attack Modifier** = your spellcasting ability modifier + your Proficiency Bonus

### Combining Magical Effects

Different spells stack their effects. However, the effects of the same spell cast multiple times don't combine—only the most powerful or most recent effect applies.

name: Armor
description:
The game features three armor categories—Light, Medium, and Heavy—each with distinct characteristics.

## Armor Training

Only those with training can use armor effectively. Untrained wearers suffer Disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity checks and saving throws, and cannot cast spells.

## Armor Categories

### Light Armor

Made from supple and thin materials, light armor favors agile adventurers since it offers some protection without sacrificing mobility.

| Armor | Armor Class | Properties |
|-------|-------------|------------|
| Padded | 11 + Dex modifier | Stealth Disadvantage |
| Leather | 11 + Dex modifier | — |
| Studded Leather | 12 + Dex modifier | — |

### Medium Armor

Medium armor offers more protection than light armor, but it also impairs movement more.

| Armor | Armor Class | Strength | Properties |
|-------|-------------|----------|------------|
| Hide | 12 + Dex modifier (max 2) | — | — |
| Chain Shirt | 13 + Dex modifier (max 2) | — | — |
| Scale Mail | 14 + Dex modifier (max 2) | — | Stealth Disadvantage |
| Breastplate | 14 + Dex modifier (max 2) | — | — |
| Half Plate | 15 + Dex modifier (max 2) | — | Stealth Disadvantage |

### Heavy Armor

Of all the armor categories, heavy armor offers the best protection. These suits of armor cover the entire body and are designed to stop a wide range of attacks.

| Armor | Armor Class | Strength | Properties |
|-------|-------------|----------|------------|
| Ring Mail | 14 | — | Stealth Disadvantage |
| Chain Mail | 16 | Str 13 | Stealth Disadvantage |
| Splint | 17 | Str 15 | Stealth Disadvantage |
| Plate | 18 | Str 15 | Stealth Disadvantage |

### Shields

A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.

## Donning and Doffing

| Category | Don | Doff |
|----------|-----|------|
| Light Armor | 1 minute | 1 minute |
| Medium Armor | 5 minutes | 1 minute |
| Heavy Armor | 10 minutes | 5 minutes |
| Shield | Utilize action | Utilize action |

## Strength Requirements

If the armor in the Armor table has a Strength requirement, the armor reduces the wearer's Speed by 10 feet unless the wearer has a Strength score equal to or higher than the listed score.

name: Weapons
description:
Your class grants proficiency in certain weapons, reflecting both the class's focus and the tools you are most likely to use.

## Weapon Categories

Two main categories structure weapon proficiencies:
- **Simple Weapons:** Basic weapons with straightforward mechanics
- **Martial Weapons:** Advanced weapons requiring specialized training

## Weapon Types

- **Melee Weapons:** Used to attack a target within 5 feet
- **Ranged Weapons:** Used for attacks at greater distances

## Weapon Properties

| Property | Effect |
|----------|--------|
| **Ammunition** | Requires ammunition to fire; expends one piece per attack; half can be recovered after combat |
| **Finesse** | Choose Strength or Dexterity modifier for both attack and damage rolls |
| **Heavy** | Disadvantage on attacks if you are Small |
| **Light** | Make bonus action attack with different light weapon after Attack action |
| **Loading** | Fire only one piece of ammunition per action, bonus action, or reaction |
| **Range** | Two distance values: normal range and long range (disadvantage beyond normal) |
| **Reach** | Adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it |
| **Thrown** | Can throw for ranged attack; draw as part of attack |
| **Two-Handed** | Requires both hands when attacking |
| **Versatile** | Use one or two hands; two-handed use increases damage |

## Weapon Mastery Properties

Eight specialized properties unlock via character features:

- **Cleave:** Extra melee attack against second nearby creature if you hit
- **Graze:** Deal ability modifier damage on missed attacks
- **Nick:** Make light weapon bonus attack as part of Attack action
- **Push:** Force creature up to 10 feet away on hit
- **Sap:** Target has disadvantage on next attack roll before your next turn
- **Slow:** Reduce target's Speed by 10 feet until start of your next turn
- **Topple:** Force Constitution saving throw or target falls Prone
- **Vex:** Gain advantage on next attack against hit target before end of your next turn

name: Charmed
description:
A creature with the Charmed condition experiences the following effects:

- **Can't Harm the Charmer.** The creature can't attack the charmer or target the charmer with damaging abilities or magical effects.
- **Social Advantage.** The charmer has Advantage on any ability check to interact socially with the creature.
