| 97 | A tiny mechanical crab or spider that moves about when it's not being observed |
| 98 | A glass jar containing lard with a label that reads, "Griffon Grease" |
| 99 | A wooden box with a ceramic bottom that holds a living worm with a head on each end of its body |
| 00 | A metal urn containing the ashes of a hero |

name: Starting at Higher Levels
description:
## Overview

Your Game Master can start your party at a level higher than 1. This is particularly recommended at level 3 for experienced D&D players.

## Creating Your Character

To create a higher-level character, follow the standard character-creation steps and apply the rules for level advancement. You begin with the minimum XP required for your starting level. For instance, starting at level 10 means beginning with 64,000 XP.

### Bonus Feats at Level 20

GMs can award feats as advancement beyond level 20. Characters gain one feat of their choice for every 30,000 XP earned above 355,000 XP. Epic Boon feats are particularly suitable, though players may select any feat their level 20 character qualifies for.

## Starting Equipment

Your GM determines whether you receive additional equipment beyond the standard level 1 package, potentially including magic items. The following table provides guidance:

| Starting Level | Equipment and Money | Magic Items |
|---|---|---|
| 2–4 | Normal starting equipment | 1 Common |
| 5–10 | 500 GP + 1d10 × 25 GP + normal equipment | 1 Common, 1 Uncommon |
| 11–16 | 5,000 GP + 1d10 × 250 GP + normal equipment | 2 Common, 3 Uncommon, 1 Rare |
| 17–20 | 20,000 GP + 1d10 × 250 GP + normal equipment | 2 Common, 4 Uncommon, 3 Rare, 1 Very Rare |

Consult your GM about available equipment purchases and whether special items like firearms are accessible.

name: Step-by-Step Character Creation
description:
## Choose a Character Sheet

Use whichever character sheet format works best for you—printed, digital, or paper—to record your character's details throughout creation.

## Create Your Character

Follow these five steps to build your character:

1. **Choose a Class** - Select your character's vocation and special talents
2. **Determine Origin** - Pick background, species, and languages
3. **Determine Ability Scores** - Generate and assign your six core abilities
4. **Choose an Alignment** - Define your character's moral compass
5. **Fill in Details** - Complete remaining calculations and selections

---

## Step 1: Choose Class

Select a class and write it on your character sheet. Reference the Class Overview table to see each class's primary focus, main ability, and complexity level.

### Class Overview

| Class | Likes | Primary Ability | Complexity |
|-------|-------|-----------------|------------|
| Barbarian | Battle | Strength | Average |
| Bard | Performing | Charisma | High |
| Cleric | Gods | Wisdom | Average |
| Druid | Nature | Wisdom | High |
| Fighter | Weapons | Str or Dex | Low |
| Monk | Unarmed combat | Dex & Wis | High |
| Paladin | Defense | Str & Cha | Average |
| Ranger | Survival | Dex & Wis | Average |
| Rogue | Stealth | Dexterity | Low |
| Sorcerer | Power | Charisma | High |
| Warlock | Occult lore | Charisma | High |
| Wizard | Spellbooks | Intelligence | Average |

### Write Your Level

Enter your character's level on the sheet. Most characters start at level 1 and advance through adventuring and Experience Points (XP).

**Write Your XP** - Record starting Experience Points. A level 1 character has 0 XP.

**Starting at a Higher Level** - If your GM begins play at level 3 or higher, also note your chosen subclass.

### Note Armor Training

Write down any armor categories your class trains you to use effectively.

---

## Step 2: Character Origin

Character origin encompasses background selection, species choice, and language acquisition.

### Choose a Background

Select a background reflecting your character's formative place and occupation.

**Record Your Feat** - Your background grants you a feat. Write this capability on your sheet.

**Note Proficiencies** - Your background provides proficiency in two skills and one tool. Your class also grants proficiencies; check your class description and record all proficiencies together. At level 1, your Proficiency Bonus is +2.

### Choose Starting Equipment

Both your background and class provide equipment. Any starting coins can purchase additional gear from the Equipment section.

### Choose a Species

Pick from: Dragonborn, Dwarf, Elf, Gnome, Goliath, Halfling, Human, Orc, or Tiefling. Write your choice and record the species' traits. Also note your character's size and Speed as determined by species.

### Imagine Your Past and Present

Use your background and species to inspire your character's history. Consider:

- Who raised you?
- Who was your dearest childhood friend?
- Did you grow up with a pet?
- Have you fallen in love? With whom?
- Did you join an organization like a guild or religion?
- What past elements inspire your adventuring?

### Choose Languages

Your character knows Common plus two additional languages.

#### Standard Languages

| 1d12 | Language |
|------|----------|
| — | Common |
| 1 | Common Sign Language |
| 2 | Draconic |
| 3–4 | Dwarvish |
| 5–6 | Elvish |
| 7 | Giant |
| 8 | Gnomish |
| 9 | Goblin |
| 10–11 | Halfling |
| 12 | Orc |

#### Rare Languages

Abyssal, Celestial, Deep Speech, Druidic, Infernal, Primordial (Aquan, Auran, Ignan, Terran), Sylvan, Thieves' Cant, Undercommon.

---

## Step 3: Ability Scores

Generate six ability scores using one method, then assign them to Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.

### Generate Your Scores

Choose one generation method:

**Standard Array** - Use these six scores: 15, 14, 13, 12, 10, 8

**Random Generation** - Roll four d6s and total the highest three. Repeat five more times for six numbers.

**Point Cost** - You have 27 points to allocate using the Ability Score Point Costs table.

#### Ability Score Point Costs

| Score | Cost |
|-------|------|
| 8 | 0 |
| 9 | 1 |
| 10 | 2 |
| 11 | 3 |
| 12 | 4 |
| 13 | 5 |
| 14 | 7 |
| 15 | 9 |

### Assign Ability Scores

Distribute your six scores among the abilities, prioritizing your class's primary ability.

#### Standard Array by Class

| Class | Str | Dex | Con | Int | Wis | Cha |
|-------|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|
| Barbarian | 15 | 13 | 14 | 10 | 12 | 8 |
| Bard | 8 | 14 | 12 | 13 | 10 | 15 |
| Cleric | 14 | 8 | 13 | 10 | 15 | 12 |
| Druid | 8 | 12 | 14 | 13 | 15 | 10 |
| Fighter | 15 | 14 | 13 | 8 | 10 | 12 |
| Monk | 12 | 15 | 13 | 10 | 14 | 8 |
| Paladin | 15 | 10 | 13 | 8 | 12 | 14 |
| Ranger | 12 | 15 | 13 | 8 | 14 | 10 |
| Rogue | 12 | 15 | 13 | 14 | 10 | 8 |
| Sorcerer | 10 | 13 | 14 | 8 | 12 | 15 |
| Warlock | 8 | 14 | 13 | 12 | 10 | 15 |
| Wizard | 8 | 12 | 13 | 15 | 14 | 10 |

### Adjust Ability Scores

Your background lists three abilities. Increase one by 2 and another by 1, OR increase all three by 1. No adjustment can raise a score above 20.

### Determine Ability Modifiers

| Score | Modifier |
|-------|----------|
| 3 | −4 |
| 4–5 | −3 |
| 6–7 | −2 |
| 8–9 | −1 |
| 10–11 | +0 |
| 12–13 | +1 |
| 14–15 | +2 |
| 16–17 | +3 |
| 18–19 | +4 |
| 20 | +5 |

---

## Step 4: Alignment

Choose your character's alignment. Player characters typically aren't evil—consult your GM before selecting an evil alignment.

### The Nine Alignments

**Lawful Good (LG)** - Characters doing what society considers right while protecting the innocent.

**Neutral Good (NG)** - Characters helping others according to need while working within rules.

**Chaotic Good (CG)** - Characters following conscience with little regard for expectations.

**Lawful Neutral (LN)** - Characters adhering to law, tradition, or personal codes.

**Neutral (N)** - Characters avoiding moral questions and doing what seems best momentarily.

**Chaotic Neutral (CN)** - Characters valuing personal freedom above all else.

**Lawful Evil (LE)** - Characters methodically taking what they want within codes of order.

**Neutral Evil (NE)** - Characters unconcerned with harm while pursuing desires.

**Chaotic Evil (CE)** - Characters acting with arbitrary violence driven by hatred.

---

## Step 5: Character Creation Details

### Record Class Features

Write down all level 1 features from your class's feature table.

### Fill In Numbers

**Saving Throws** - For proficient saving throws, add your Proficiency Bonus to the relevant ability modifier.

**Skills** - For proficient skills, add your Proficiency Bonus to the associated ability modifier.

**Passive Perception** - Calculate using: 10 + Wisdom (Perception) check modifier.

**Hit Points** - Consult the Level 1 Hit Points by Class table.

#### Level 1 Hit Points by Class

| Class | Hit Point Maximum |
|-------|-------------------|
| Barbarian | 12 + Con modifier |
| Fighter, Paladin, Ranger | 10 + Con modifier |
| Bard, Cleric, Druid, Monk, Rogue, Warlock | 8 + Con modifier |
| Sorcerer, Wizard | 6 + Con modifier |

**Hit Point Dice** - Write your class's Hit Die type. You begin with 1 Hit Die.

**Initiative** - Write your Dexterity modifier in the Initiative space.

**Armor Class** - Without armor or shield, your base AC is 10 plus your Dexterity modifier.

**Attacks** - List your starting weapons. Calculate attack bonuses:
- Melee: Strength modifier + Proficiency Bonus
- Ranged: Dexterity modifier + Proficiency Bonus

**Spellcasting** - If you cast spells, calculate:
- Spell Save DC: 8 + spellcasting ability modifier + Proficiency Bonus
- Spell Attack Bonus: spellcasting ability modifier + Proficiency Bonus

name: Deafened
description:
A creature with the Deafened condition experiences the following effects:

- **Can't Hear.** The creature can't hear and automatically fails any ability check that requires hearing.

name: Exhaustion
description:
The Exhaustion condition is cumulative. Each time you receive it, you gain 1 Exhaustion level. You die if your Exhaustion level is 6.

## Effects by Level

| Level | Effect |
|-------|--------|
| 1 | Disadvantage on D20 Tests |
| 2 | Speed halved |
| 3 | Disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws |
| 4 | Hit Point maximum halved |
| 5 | Speed reduced to 0 |
| 6 | Death |

When you make a D20 Test, the roll is reduced by 2 times your Exhaustion level.

Your Speed is reduced by a number of feet equal to 5 times your Exhaustion level.

## Removing Exhaustion

Finishing a Long Rest removes 1 of your Exhaustion levels. An effect that removes exhaustion reduces its level as specified, with all effects ending if your exhaustion level is reduced below 1.

name: Incapacitated
description:
A creature with the Incapacitated condition experiences the following effects:

- **Inactive.** The creature can't take actions, bonus actions, or reactions.

name: Rhythm of Play
description:
The fundamental structure of D&D gameplay revolves around three core pillars: social interaction, exploration, and combat. Regardless of which element is being experienced, play follows a consistent cycle:

1. **The Game Master Describes a Scene.** The GM sets the stage by explaining the adventurers' location and surrounding details such as available exits, objects, and environmental features.

2. **The Players Describe What Their Characters Do.** While characters typically travel together, they may pursue separate activities - one character might open a chest while another inspects a wall carving and a third watches for threats. The GM manages turn order outside combat and resolves actions, whereas combat uses a formal turn-based system.

3. **The GM Narrates the Results of the Adventurers' Actions.** Simple tasks may resolve immediately, such as opening an unlocked door. However, obstacles like locked doors, traps, or other complications may require dice rolls to determine outcomes. Describing the results often leads to another decision point, which brings the game back to step 1.

This three-step cycle repeats throughout every session, whether characters are negotiating with nobility, investigating ruins, or engaging in combat. Combat situations employ more structured mechanics with sequential turns.

## Exceptions Supersede General Rules

General rules provide the foundation for gameplay mechanics. However, specific features - class abilities, feats, weapon properties, spells, magic items, and monster abilities - sometimes override these baseline rules. When conflicts arise, the specific exception takes precedence over the general rule.

name: The Six Abilities
description:
All creatures - characters and monsters - have six abilities that measure physical and mental characteristics, as shown on the Ability Descriptions table.

## Ability Descriptions

| Ability | Score Measures... |
|---------|-------------------|
| Strength | Physical might |
| Dexterity | Agility, reflexes, and balance |
| Constitution | Health and stamina |
| Intelligence | Reasoning and memory |
| Wisdom | Perceptiveness and mental fortitude |
| Charisma | Confidence, poise and charm |

## Ability Scores

Each ability has a score from 1 to 20, although some monsters have a score as high as 30. The score represents the magnitude of an ability. The Ability Scores table summarizes what the scores mean.

### Ability Score Meanings

| Score | Meaning |
|-------|--------|
| 1 | This is the lowest a score can normally go. If an effect reduces a score to 0, that effect explains what happens. |
| 2-9 | This represents a weak ability. |
| 10-11 | This represents the human average. |
| 12-19 | This represents a strong capability. |
| 20 | This is the highest an adventurer's score can go unless a feature says otherwise. |
| 21-29 | This represents an extraordinary capability. |
| 30 | This is the highest a score can go. |

## Ability Modifiers

Each ability has a modifier that you apply whenever you make a D20 Test with that ability. An ability modifier is derived from its score, as shown in the Ability Modifiers table.

**Round Down:** Whenever you divide or multiply a number in the game, round down if you end up with a fraction, even if the fraction is one-half or greater.

### Ability Modifiers Table

| Score | Modifier |
|-------|----------|
| 1 | -5 |
| 2-3 | -4 |
| 4-5 | -3 |
| 6-7 | -2 |
| 8-9 | -1 |
| 10-11 | +0 |
| 12-13 | +1 |
| 14-15 | +2 |
| 16-17 | +3 |
| 18-19 | +4 |
| 20-21 | +5 |
| 22-23 | +6 |
| 24-25 | +7 |
| 26-27 | +8 |
| 28-29 | +9 |
| 30 | +10 |

name: Proficiency
description:
Characters and monsters excel at different tasks. The degree to which they succeed relates to their Proficiency Bonus, which reflects training and increases with character level or monster Challenge Rating. This bonus applies to D20 Tests when the creature has proficiency in a skill, saving throw, or equipment used for that test. It also factors into spell attacks and spell save DCs.

## Proficiency Bonus Table

| Level or CR | Bonus |
|-------------|-------|
| Up to 4 | +2 |
| 5-8 | +3 |
| 9-12 | +4 |
| 13-16 | +5 |
| 17-20 | +6 |
| 21-24 | +7 |
| 25-28 | +8 |
| 29-30 | +9 |

## The Bonus Doesn't Stack

Your Proficiency Bonus can't be added to a die roll or another number more than once. While the bonus may be multiplied or divided (such as through Expertise), it applies only once per roll.

## Skill Proficiencies

Creatures with skill proficiency add their Proficiency Bonus to related ability checks. Without proficiency, ability checks are still possible but lack this bonus.

### Skill List

| Skill | Ability | Example Uses |
|-------|---------|-------------|
| Acrobatics | Dexterity | Stay on your feet in tricky situations or perform acrobatic stunts |
| Animal Handling | Wisdom | Calm, train, or direct animals |
| Arcana | Intelligence | Recall lore about spells, magic items, and planes |
| Athletics | Strength | Jump farther, stay afloat, or break objects |
| Deception | Charisma | Tell convincing lies or wear disguises |
| History | Intelligence | Recall lore about historical events and cultures |
| Insight | Wisdom | Discern a person's mood and intentions |
| Intimidation | Charisma | Awe or threaten someone |
| Investigation | Intelligence | Find obscure information or deduce mechanics |
| Medicine | Wisdom | Diagnose illness or determine cause of death |
| Nature | Intelligence | Recall lore about terrain, plants, and weather |
| Perception | Wisdom | Notice things easy to miss using senses |
| Performance | Charisma | Act, tell stories, perform music, or dance |
| Persuasion | Charisma | Convince someone honestly and graciously |
| Religion | Intelligence | Recall lore about gods and rituals |
| Sleight of Hand | Dexterity | Pick pockets or perform legerdemain |
| Stealth | Dexterity | Move quietly and hide |
| Survival | Wisdom | Follow tracks, forage, or avoid hazards |

## Saving Throw Proficiencies

Proficiency in saving throws allows a character to add their Proficiency Bonus to saves using a particular ability. Each class grants proficiency in at least two saving throws, reflecting training in resisting specific threats.

## Equipment Proficiencies

**Weapons:** Proficiency allows you to add your Proficiency Bonus to attack rolls made with that weapon.

**Tools:** Tool proficiency permits adding your Proficiency Bonus to relevant ability checks. If you're also proficient in the related skill, you gain Advantage on that check.

name: Actions
description:
When you do something other than moving or communicating, you typically take an action. The Action table lists the game's main actions.

## Action Table

| Action | Summary |
|--------|--------|
| Attack | Attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike. |
| Dash | For the rest of the turn, give yourself extra movement equal to your Speed. |
| Disengage | Your movement doesn't provoke Opportunity Attacks for the rest of the turn. |
| Dodge | Until the start of your next turn, attack rolls against you have Disadvantage, and you make Dexterity saving throws with Advantage. You lose this benefit if you have the Incapacitated condition or if your Speed is 0. |
| Help | Help another creature's ability check or attack roll, or administer first aid. |
| Hide | Make a Dexterity (Stealth) check. |
| Influence | Make a Charisma (Deception, Intimidation, Performance, or Persuasion) or Wisdom (Animal Handling) check to alter a creature's attitude. |
| Magic | Cast a spell, use a magic item, or use a magical feature. |
| Ready | Prepare to take an action in response to a trigger you define. |
| Search | Make a Wisdom (Insight, Medicine, Perception, or Survival) check. |
| Study | Make an Intelligence (Arcana, History, Investigation, Nature, or Religion) check. |
| Utilize | Use a nonmagical object. |

Player characters and monsters can also do things not covered by these actions. Many class features and other abilities provide additional action options, and you can improvise other actions. When you describe an action not detailed elsewhere in the rules, the Game Master tells you whether that action is possible and what kind of D20 Test you need to make, if any.

## One Thing at a Time

You can take only one action at a time. This principle applies throughout gameplay, whether during combat or other situations. During social interactions, you might attempt to influence a creature or read body language, but not simultaneously. Similarly, while exploring, you cannot search for traps while helping another character open a stuck door.

## Bonus Actions

Various class features, spells, and other abilities grant an additional action called a Bonus Action. You can take a Bonus Action only when a special ability, a spell, or another feature of the game states that you can do something as a Bonus Action.

Key restrictions include taking only one Bonus Action per turn and choosing which to use if multiple options exist. The timing of Bonus Actions is at your discretion unless otherwise specified. Any condition that prevents standard actions also prevents Bonus Actions.

## Reactions

Certain abilities, spells, and situations enable a special action called a Reaction. A Reaction is an instant response to a trigger of some kind, which can occur on your turn or on someone else's. The Opportunity Attack represents the most common reaction type.

Once you take a Reaction, you cannot take another until the start of your subsequent turn. If the reaction interrupts another creature's turn, that creature continues afterward.

name: Social Interaction
description:
During adventures, player characters encounter numerous NPCs and creatures preferring dialogue to combat. Social interactions take varied forms - convincing a burglar to confess or flattering a guard are examples. The Game Master portrays all nonplayer characters involved.

An NPC's disposition toward your character falls into three categories: Friendly, Indifferent, or Hostile. Friendly NPCs are inclined to provide assistance, while Hostile ones tend to obstruct.

Social interactions unfold through two mechanisms: roleplaying and ability checks.

## Roleplaying

Roleplaying involves embodying your character's personality, determining their thoughts, actions, and speech. This core mechanic appears throughout the game but becomes especially prominent during social encounters.

Consider whether you favor an active or descriptive approach when roleplaying.

The GM uses an NPC's established personality alongside your character's actions and attitudes to determine responses. A fearful bandit might surrender to imprisonment threats. A stubborn merchant refuses help if badgered. A conceited dragon enjoys flattery.

During NPC interactions, observe the GM's characterization carefully. Understanding an NPC's objectives helps you influence their behavior effectively.

Offering NPCs desired items or appealing to their sympathies, anxieties, or motivations can cultivate alliances, prevent conflict, or reveal crucial information. Conversely, insulting an honorable warrior or denigrating a nobleman's companions will probably undermine your persuasion or deception attempts.

## Ability Checks

Ability checks prove instrumental in determining social interaction outcomes. While roleplaying can shift an NPC's attitude, chance elements may factor in when the GM opts for dice-based resolution. The GM typically requests the Influence action in these scenarios.

Consider your skill proficiencies when planning NPC interactions; employ approaches leveraging your group's strengths. For instance, when deceiving a guard, the Rogue with Deception proficiency should take the lead.

name: Gaining Spells
description:
Before casting a spell, you must have it prepared mentally or access it via magic items like Spell Scrolls. Your class features specify which spells you can access and how preparation works.

## Preparing Spells

If your class has preparable spells, the timing and quantity depend on your class:

| Class | Change When | Number |
|-------|------------|--------|
| Bard | Gain level | One |
| Cleric | Long Rest | Any |
| Druid | Long Rest | Any |
| Paladin | Long Rest | One |
| Ranger | Long Rest | One |
| Sorcerer | Gain level | One |
| Warlock | Gain level | One |
| Wizard | Long Rest | Any |

**Always-Prepared Spells.** Certain features grant spells you always have prepared, which don't count toward your preparation limit.

## Spell Sources

Characters gain access to spells through various means:

- **Class Features:** Your class determines your spell list and how you learn or prepare spells
- **Subclass Features:** Some subclasses grant additional spells or expand your options
- **Feats:** Certain feats grant access to specific spells
- **Magic Items:** Spell Scrolls, wands, and other items can provide spell access
- **Species Traits:** Some species have innate spellcasting abilities

name: Casting Spells
description:
This section covers the mechanics of casting spells, including spell slots, casting time, and restrictions.

## Casting in Armor

You must have training with any armor you are wearing to cast spells while wearing it. If you lack proficiency with the armor you're wearing, you cannot cast spells.

## Spell Levels

Spells range from level 0 to level 9, indicating their power level. Cantrips—simple spells that can be cast almost by rote—are level 0.

## Spell Slots

When you cast a spell of level 1 or higher, you expend a slot of that spell's level or higher. Spell slots are restored after a Long Rest (or Short Rest for some classes like Warlocks).

## Casting Without Slots

**Cantrips.** Level 0 spells can be cast at will without expending spell slots.

**Rituals.** Spells with the Ritual tag can be cast in a ritual version that takes 10 minutes longer but doesn't expend a spell slot.

**Special Abilities.** Some class features and feats allow you to cast certain spells without expending a slot, typically once per Long Rest.

**Magic Items.** Spell Scrolls and other magic items may allow you to cast spells without using your own spell slots.

## Using Higher-Level Spell Slots

When a spellcaster casts a spell using a slot that is of a higher level than the spell, the spell takes on the higher level for that casting. Some spells have more powerful effects when cast at higher levels, as detailed in the spell's description.

## One Spell Slot Per Turn

On a turn, you can expend only one spell slot to cast a spell. This means if you cast a spell as a Bonus Action, any other spell you cast on that turn must be a cantrip with a casting time of one action.

## Casting Time

Most spells require one action to cast using the Magic action. Some spells use a Bonus Action, a Reaction, or take 1 minute or longer.

### Longer Casting Times

Spells requiring 1 minute or longer demand the Magic action each turn and maintained Concentration. If your Concentration is broken, the spell fails but you don't lose the spell slot.

## Range

Spells have ranges expressed as a distance in feet, Touch, or Self. Once a spell is cast, its effects aren't limited by range unless the spell description says otherwise.

## Schools of Magic

Eight schools categorize spells by their effect type:
- **Abjuration:** Protective spells
- **Conjuration:** Transporting objects and creatures
- **Divination:** Revealing information
- **Enchantment:** Affecting minds
- **Evocation:** Channeling energy for damage or healing
- **Illusion:** Deceiving the senses
- **Necromancy:** Manipulating life force
- **Transmutation:** Changing properties

## Saving Throws and Attack Rolls

**Spell Save DC** = 8 + your spellcasting ability modifier + your Proficiency Bonus

**Spell Attack Modifier** = your spellcasting ability modifier + your Proficiency Bonus

### Combining Magical Effects

Different spells stack their effects. However, the effects of the same spell cast multiple times don't combine—only the most powerful or most recent effect applies.

name: Spell Components
description:
Spells may require Verbal (V), Somatic (S), or Material (M) components. Each spell's description lists which components are required.

## Verbal (V)

Casting a spell with a verbal component requires speaking mystic words. Being silenced or in an area of magical silence prevents casting spells with V components.

The words themselves aren't the source of the spell's power; rather, the particular combination of sounds, with specific pitch and resonance, sets the threads of magic in motion.

## Somatic (S)

Casting a spell with a somatic component requires hand gestures. You must have a free hand to make these gestures, or you can use the same hand holding your spellcasting focus.

The gestures might include forceful gesticulation or an intricate set of motions. If a spell requires a somatic component, the caster must have free use of at least one hand to perform these gestures.

## Material (M)

Casting a spell with a material component requires specific items. These items are listed in parentheses in the Components entry of the spell.

### Component Pouches and Focuses

A Component Pouch or Spellcasting Focus can substitute for most material components. However, if a component has a listed cost or is consumed by the spell, you must have that specific component.

**Component Pouch:** A small, watertight leather belt pouch containing all the material components needed for your spells, except those with a cost.

**Spellcasting Focus:** An object—such as a crystal, orb, rod, staff, wand, or holy symbol—specially designed to channel the power of spells. A character can use such an object as described in the class features.

### Consumed Components

Some spells specify that their material components are consumed by the casting. You must provide these components fresh for each casting.

### Costly Components

If a spell specifies a gold piece cost for a component, you must have components worth at least that much. A spellcasting focus or component pouch cannot replace such a component.

name: Blinded
description:
A creature with the Blinded condition experiences the following effects:

- **Can't See.** The creature can't see and automatically fails any ability check that requires sight.
- **Attacks Affected.** Attack rolls against the creature have Advantage, and the creature's attack rolls have Disadvantage.

name: Frightened
description:
A creature with the Frightened condition experiences the following effects:

- **Disadvantage on Checks and Attacks.** The creature has Disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls while the source of its fear is within line of sight.
- **Can't Approach.** The creature can't willingly move closer to the source of its fear.

name: Grappled
description:
A creature with the Grappled condition experiences the following effects:

- **Speed 0.** The creature's Speed is 0 and can't increase.
- **Attacks Affected.** The creature has Disadvantage on attack rolls against any target other than the grappler.
- **Movable.** The grappler can drag or carry the creature when it moves, but every foot of movement costs the grappler 1 extra foot unless the creature is Tiny or two or more sizes smaller than the grappler.

## Ending the Condition

The condition ends if the grappler becomes Incapacitated or if an effect removes the grappled creature from the reach of the grappler or grappling effect.

name: Invisible
description:
A creature with the Invisible condition experiences the following effects:

- **Surprise Attack.** The creature can't be seen without the aid of magic or a special sense. For the purposes of hiding, the creature is Heavily Obscured. The creature's location can be detected by noise or tracks.
- **Attacks Affected.** Attack rolls against the creature have Disadvantage, and the creature's attack rolls have Advantage.

name: Paralyzed
description:
A creature with the Paralyzed condition experiences the following effects:

- **Incapacitated.** The creature has the Incapacitated condition.
- **Speed 0.** The creature's Speed is 0 and can't increase.
- **Saving Throws Affected.** The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
- **Attacks Affected.** Attack rolls against the creature have Advantage.
- **Automatic Critical Hits.** Any attack that hits the creature is a Critical Hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.

name: Petrified
description:
A creature with the Petrified condition experiences the following effects:

- **Turned to Stone.** The creature is transformed, along with nonmagical objects it's wearing or carrying, into a solid, inanimate substance. Its weight increases by a factor of ten, and it ceases aging.
- **Incapacitated.** The creature has the Incapacitated condition.
- **Speed 0.** The creature's Speed is 0 and can't increase.
- **Attacks Affected.** Attack rolls against the creature have Advantage.
- **Saving Throws Affected.** The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
- **Resistance.** The creature has Resistance to all damage.
- **Poison Immunity.** The creature is immune to the Poisoned condition and to poison damage, although any poison or disease already in its system is only suspended, not neutralized.

name: Poisoned
description:
A creature with the Poisoned condition experiences the following effects:

- **Ability Checks and Attacks Affected.** The creature has Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

name: Prone
description:
A creature with the Prone condition experiences the following effects:

- **Movement Options.** The creature's only movement options are to crawl or to spend an amount of movement equal to half its Speed (round down) to stand up and end the condition.
- **Attacks Affected.** The creature has Disadvantage on attack rolls. An attack roll against the creature has Advantage if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature. Otherwise, the attack roll has Disadvantage.

name: Restrained
description:
A creature with the Restrained condition experiences the following effects:

- **Speed 0.** The creature's Speed is 0 and can't increase.
- **Attacks Affected.** Attack rolls against the creature have Advantage, and the creature's attack rolls have Disadvantage.
- **Saving Throws Affected.** The creature has Disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws.

name: Stunned
description:
A creature with the Stunned condition experiences the following effects:

- **Incapacitated.** The creature has the Incapacitated condition.
- **Speed 0.** The creature's Speed is 0 and can't increase.
- **Saving Throws Affected.** The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
- **Attacks Affected.** Attack rolls against the creature have Advantage.

name: Unconscious
description:
A creature with the Unconscious condition experiences the following effects:

- **Incapacitated.** The creature has the Incapacitated condition.
- **Speed 0.** The creature's Speed is 0 and can't increase.
- **Drops Items.** The creature drops whatever it's holding and falls Prone.
- **Saving Throws Affected.** The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
- **Attacks Affected.** Attack rolls against the creature have Advantage.
- **Automatic Critical Hits.** Any attack that hits the creature is a Critical Hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.

name: Resting
description:
Heroic though they might be, adventurers can't spend every hour in pursuit of adventure. They need to rest—time to sleep and eat, tend their wounds, refresh their minds and spirits for spellcasting, and brace themselves for further adventure.

Adventurers can take Short Rests in the midst of a day and a Long Rest to end it.

## Short Rest

A Short Rest is a period of downtime, at least 1 hour long, during which a character does nothing more strenuous than eating, drinking, reading, and tending to wounds.

### Using Hit Dice

A character can spend one or more Hit Dice at the end of a Short Rest, up to the character's maximum number of Hit Dice, which equals the character's level. For each Hit Die spent in this way, the player rolls the die and adds the character's Constitution modifier to it. The character regains Hit Points equal to the total (minimum of 0). The player can decide to spend an additional Hit Die after each roll.

### Recovering Short Rest Abilities

Some class features and other abilities recharge after a Short Rest. Consult those features for details.

## Long Rest

A Long Rest is a period of extended downtime, at least 8 hours long, during which a character sleeps for at least 6 hours and performs no more than 2 hours of light activity, such as reading, talking, eating, or standing watch.

### Benefits of a Long Rest

At the end of a Long Rest, a character regains all lost Hit Points and spent Hit Dice (up to a number of dice equal to half of the character's total number of them). In addition, the character's exhaustion level decreases by 1, and they regain all spent spell slots.

### Long Rest Limitations

A character can't benefit from more than one Long Rest in a 24-hour period, and a character must have at least 1 Hit Point at the start of the rest to gain its benefits.

### Interrupting a Long Rest

If a Long Rest is interrupted by a period of strenuous activity—at least 1 hour of walking, fighting, casting spells, or similar adventuring activity—the characters must begin the rest again to gain any benefit from it.

name: Level Advancement
description:
Characters gain Experience Points (XP) during adventures. When XP totals match or exceed thresholds in the Character Advancement table, the character advances to the corresponding level, gaining new capabilities and increasing their Proficiency Bonus at certain milestones.

## Character Advancement Table

| Level | XP | Proficiency Bonus |
|-------|-----|------------------|
| 1 | 0 | +2 |
| 2 | 300 | +2 |
| 3 | 900 | +2 |
| 4 | 2,700 | +2 |
| 5 | 6,500 | +3 |
| 6 | 14,000 | +3 |
| 7 | 23,000 | +3 |
| 8 | 34,000 | +3 |
| 9 | 48,000 | +4 |
| 10 | 64,000 | +4 |
| 11 | 85,000 | +4 |
| 12 | 100,000 | +4 |
| 13 | 120,000 | +5 |
| 14 | 140,000 | +5 |
| 15 | 165,000 | +5 |
| 16 | 195,000 | +5 |
| 17 | 225,000 | +6 |
| 18 | 265,000 | +6 |
| 19 | 305,000 | +6 |
| 20 | 355,000 | +6 |

## When Gaining a Level

Follow these steps when your character gains a level:

1. **Choose a Class.** Most characters advance in their current class, though multiclassing is an option.

2. **Adjust Hit Points.** Gain an additional Hit Die. Roll it, add your Constitution modifier (minimum 1 total), and add to your HP maximum. Alternatively, use fixed values based on your class Hit Die.

3. **Record New Class Features.** Consult your class table and note new features gained at your new level.

4. **Adjust Proficiency Bonus.** Update all affected numbers on your character sheet when this bonus increases.

5. **Adjust Ability Modifiers.** If ability scores reach even numbers through feats, update related calculations. A Constitution modifier increase adds 1 HP per character level already attained.

name: Multiclassing
description:
Multiclassing enables characters to gain levels in multiple classes by choosing a new class when advancing levels instead of progressing in their current class.

## Prerequisites

Characters must have ability scores of at least 13 in the primary ability for both their current and new classes. For instance, a Barbarian/Druid multiclass requires minimum Strength and Wisdom scores of 13.

## Experience and Leveling

The Experience Point cost to gain a level is based on your total character level, not your level in a particular class.

## Hit Points and Hit Dice

New class Hit Points follow standard progression rules. Hit Dice pool together if they match types (e.g., d10s combine), but separate tracking applies for different die types.

## Proficiency Bonus

Your Proficiency Bonus depends on your total character level. A level 3 Fighter/level 2 Rogue has a +3 bonus as a level 5 character.

## Proficiencies

When you gain your first level in a class other than your initial class, you gain only some of the new class's starting proficiencies.

### Multiclass Proficiencies Table

| Class | Proficiencies Gained |
|-------|---------------------|
| Barbarian | Shields, Simple weapons, Martial weapons |
| Bard | Light armor, one skill, one musical instrument |
| Cleric | Light armor, Medium armor, Shields |
| Druid | Light armor, Medium armor, Shields |
| Fighter | Light armor, Medium armor, Shields, Simple weapons, Martial weapons |
| Monk | Simple weapons |
| Paladin | Light armor, Medium armor, Shields, Simple weapons, Martial weapons |
| Ranger | Light armor, Medium armor, Shields, Simple weapons, Martial weapons, one skill |
| Rogue | Light armor, one skill |
| Sorcerer | — |
| Warlock | Light armor, Simple weapons |
| Wizard | — |

## Armor Class

Only one AC calculation method applies at a time. Characters cannot stack Unarmored Defense with Draconic Resilience.

## Extra Attack

Extra Attack features don't stack—you gain a maximum of two attacks unless a specific feature permits more.

## Spellcasting

Spell slots combine using the Multiclass Spellcaster table. Add together all your levels in Bard, Cleric, Druid, Sorcerer, and Wizard, plus half your levels (rounded down) in Paladin and Ranger. Use this total to determine your spell slots.

You know and prepare spells for each class separately, using that class's spellcasting ability for those spells.

name: Spell Duration
description:
A spell's duration is the length of time the spell persists. Duration can be expressed in rounds, minutes, hours, or even years. Some spells specify that their effects last until dispelled or destroyed.

## Instantaneous

The spell's magic vanishes immediately after casting, though its effects might persist. An instantaneous spell cannot be dispelled because its magic exists only for a moment.

## Concentration

Some spells require you to maintain concentration to keep their magic active. If you lose concentration, such a spell ends.

### Maintaining Concentration

Normal activity—such as moving and attacking—doesn't interfere with concentration. The following factors can break concentration:

**Casting another concentration spell.** You lose concentration on a spell if you cast another spell that requires concentration.

**Taking damage.** Whenever you take damage while concentrating on a spell, you must make a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration. The DC equals 10 or half the damage taken, whichever is higher.

**Being incapacitated or killed.** You lose concentration if you are incapacitated or if you die.

**Environmental interference.** The GM might also decide that certain environmental phenomena, such as a wave crashing over you while you're on a storm-tossed ship, require you to succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration.

### Ending Concentration

You can end concentration at any time (no action required).

## Time Span

Some spells last for a specific duration, such as 1 minute or 8 hours. The spell's magic persists for this duration unless:

- The spell is dispelled
- The spell specifies conditions that end it early
- The caster dismisses it (if permitted by the spell)

You can dismiss a spell you cast if you are not Incapacitated and the spell doesn't require concentration. Dismissing a spell doesn't require an action.

name: Spell Targets
description:
A typical spell requires the caster to pick one or more targets to be affected by the spell's magic. A spell's description tells you whether the spell targets creatures, objects, or a point of origin for an area of effect.

## Targeting Requirements

To target something with a spell, you must have a clear path to it. If you place an area of effect at a point you can't see and an obstruction is between you and that point, the point of origin comes into being on the near side of that obstruction.

### Line of Sight

Unless a spell has a visible effect or the spell says otherwise, a creature doesn't know it is being targeted by a spell.

### Targeting Yourself

If a spell targets a creature of your choice, you can choose yourself, unless the creature must be hostile or specifically a creature other than you.

### Invalid Targets

If a target is invalid (like targeting a creature immune to the spell's effect or a target behind total cover), the spell slot is expended but the spell has no effect on that target.

## Areas of Effect

Spells such as *burning hands* and *cone of cold* cover an area, allowing them to affect multiple creatures at once. A spell's description specifies its area of effect, which typically has one of six shapes:

### Cone

A cone extends in a direction you choose from its point of origin. A cone's width at a given point along its length is equal to that point's distance from the point of origin. A cone's area of effect specifies its maximum length.

### Cube

You select a cube's point of origin, which lies anywhere on a face of the cubic effect. The cube's size is expressed as the length of each side.

### Cylinder

A cylinder's point of origin is the center of a circle of a particular radius. The circle must either be on the ground or at the height of the spell effect. The energy in a cylinder expands in straight lines from the point of origin to the perimeter of the circle, forming the base of the cylinder.

### Emanation

An emanation extends in straight lines from a creature or object in all directions. Its size is determined by the radius from the creature or object at its center.

### Line

A line extends from its point of origin in a straight path up to its length and covers an area defined by its width.

### Sphere

You select a sphere's point of origin, and the sphere extends outward from that point. The sphere's size is expressed as a radius in feet that extends from the point.

name: Damage Types
description:
Attacks, spells, and other harmful effects deal different types of damage. Damage types have no rules of their own, but other rules, such as Resistance, rely on the types.

| Type | Examples |
|------|----------|
| Acid | Corrosive liquids, digestive enzymes |
| Bludgeoning | Blunt objects, constriction, falling |
| Cold | Freezing water, icy blasts |
| Fire | Flames, unbearable heat |
| Force | Pure magical energy |
| Lightning | Electricity |
| Necrotic | Life-draining energy |
| Piercing | Fangs, puncturing objects |
| Poison | Toxic gas, venom |
| Psychic | Mind-rending energy |
| Radiant | Holy energy, searing radiation |
| Slashing | Claws, cutting objects |
| Thunder | Concussive sound |

name: Creature Types
description:
Every creature in D&D belongs to a creature type. The creature types are: Aberration, Beast, Celestial, Construct, Dragon, Elemental, Fey, Fiend, Giant, Humanoid, Monstrosity, Ooze, Plant, and Undead.

A creature's type doesn't determine abilities, but some spells, magic items, class features, and other effects have special interactions with creatures of certain types.

name: Burning
description: A burning creature or object takes 1d4 Fire damage at the start of each of its turns. As an action, you can extinguish fire on yourself by giving yourself the Prone condition and rolling on the ground. The fire also goes out if it is doused, submerged, or suffocated.

name: Dehydration
description:
A creature requires an amount of water per day based on its size. A creature that drinks less than half the required water for a day gains 1 Exhaustion level at the day's end. Exhaustion caused by dehydration can't be removed until the creature drinks the full amount of water required for a day.

| Size | Water per Day |
|------|---------------|
| Tiny | 1/4 gallon |
| Small | 1 gallon |
| Medium | 1 gallon |
| Large | 4 gallons |
| Huge | 16 gallons |
| Gargantuan | 64 gallons |

name: Falling
description:
A creature that falls takes 1d6 Bludgeoning damage at the end of the fall for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d6. When the creature lands, it has the Prone condition unless it avoids taking any damage from the fall.

A creature that falls into water or another liquid can use its Reaction to make a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to hit the surface head or feet first. On a successful check, any damage resulting from the fall is halved.

name: Malnutrition
description:
A creature needs an amount of food per day based on its size. A creature that eats but consumes less than half the required food for a day must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Exhaustion level at the day's end. A creature that eats nothing for 5 days automatically gains 1 Exhaustion level at the end of the fifth day as well as an additional level at the end of each subsequent day without food.

| Size | Food per Day |
|------|---------------|
| Tiny | 1/4 pound |
| Small | 1 pound |
| Medium | 1 pound |
| Large | 4 pounds |
| Huge | 16 pounds |
| Gargantuan | 64 pounds |

name: Suffocation
description: A creature can hold its breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 plus its Constitution modifier (minimum of 30 seconds) before suffocation begins. When a creature runs out of breath or is choking, it gains 1 Exhaustion level at the end of each of its turns. When a creature can breathe again, it removes all levels of Exhaustion it gained from suffocating.

name: Deep Water
description: Swimming through deep water (more than 100 feet deep) presents additional challenges because of the water's pressure and cold temperature. After each hour of swimming in deep water, a creature that lacks a Swim Speed must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Exhaustion level.

name: Extreme Cold
description: When the temperature is 0 degrees Fahrenheit or lower, a creature exposed to the extreme cold must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw at the end of each hour or gain 1 Exhaustion level. Creatures that have Resistance or Immunity to Cold damage automatically succeed on the save.

name: Extreme Heat
description: When the temperature is 100 degrees Fahrenheit or higher, a creature exposed to the extreme heat and without access to drinkable water must succeed on a Constitution saving throw at the end of each hour or gain 1 Exhaustion level. The DC is 5 for the first hour and increases by 1 for each additional hour. Creatures wearing Medium or Heavy armor have Disadvantage on the save. Creatures that have Resistance or Immunity to Fire damage automatically succeed on the save.

name: Frigid Water
description: A creature can be immersed in frigid water for a number of minutes equal to its Constitution score before suffering any ill effects. Each additional minute spent in frigid water requires the creature to succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Exhaustion level. Creatures with Resistance or Immunity to Cold damage automatically succeed on the save, as do creatures that are naturally adapted to living in ice-cold water.

name: Heavy Precipitation
description: Everything within an area of heavy rain or heavy snowfall is Lightly Obscured, and creatures in the area have Disadvantage on all Wisdom (Perception) checks. Heavy rain also extinguishes open flames.

name: High Altitude
description: Traveling at altitudes of 10,000 feet or higher above sea level is taxing for most creatures because of the reduced amount of oxygen in the air. Each hour such a creature spends traveling at high altitude counts as 2 hours for the purpose of determining how long that creature can travel. Creatures can become acclimated to a high altitude by spending 30 days or more at this elevation. Creatures can't become acclimated to elevations above 20,000 feet unless they are native to such environments.

name: Slippery Ice
description: Slippery ice is Difficult Terrain. A creature that moves onto slippery ice for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or have the Prone condition.

name: Strong Wind
description: Strong wind imposes Disadvantage on ranged attack rolls with weapons. It also extinguishes open flames and disperses fog. A flying creature in a strong wind must land at the end of its turn or fall. A strong wind in a desert can create a sandstorm that imposes Disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks.

name: Thin Ice
description: Thin ice has a weight tolerance of 3d10 x 10 pounds per 10-foot-square area. Whenever the total weight on an area of thin ice exceeds its tolerance, the ice in that area breaks. All creatures on broken ice fall through. Below the ice is frigid water.

name: Travel Terrain
description:
Different terrain types affect travel pace, encounter distance, and skill check DCs.

| Terrain | Max Pace | Encounter Distance | Foraging DC | Navigation DC | Search DC |
|---------|----------|-------------------|-------------|---------------|----------|
| Arctic | Fast* | 6d6 x 10 ft | DC 20 | DC 10 | DC 10 |
| Coastal | Normal | 2d10 x 10 ft | DC 10 | DC 5 | DC 15 |
| Desert | Normal | 6d6 x 10 ft | DC 20 | DC 10 | DC 10 |
| Forest | Normal | 2d8 x 10 ft | DC 10 | DC 15 | DC 15 |
| Grassland | Fast | 6d6 x 10 ft | DC 15 | DC 5 | DC 15 |
| Hill | Normal | 2d10 x 10 ft | DC 15 | DC 10 | DC 15 |
| Mountain | Slow | 4d10 x 10 ft | DC 20 | DC 15 | DC 20 |
| Swamp | Slow | 2d8 x 10 ft | DC 10 | DC 15 | DC 20 |
| Underdark | Normal | 2d6 x 10 ft | DC 20 | DC 10 | DC 20 |
| Urban | Normal | 2d6 x 10 ft | DC 20 | DC 15 | DC 15 |
| Waterborne | Special | 6d6 x 10 ft | DC 15 | DC 10 | DC 15 |

*Arctic terrain requires appropriate equipment (such as skis) to maintain Fast pace.

**Extended Travel:** Characters can push themselves to travel for more than 8 hours per day. At the end of each additional hour of travel beyond 8 hours, each character must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Exhaustion level. The DC is 10 plus 1 for each hour past 8 hours.

name: Carrying Capacity
description:
Your carrying capacity is how much weight you can carry. Your size determines your base carrying capacity and your capacity for pushing, dragging, or lifting weight.

| Size | Carry | Push/Drag/Lift |
|------|-------|----------------|
| Tiny | Str x 7.5 lb | Str x 15 lb |
| Small/Medium | Str x 15 lb | Str x 30 lb |
| Large | Str x 30 lb | Str x 60 lb |
| Huge | Str x 60 lb | Str x 120 lb |
| Gargantuan | Str x 120 lb | Str x 240 lb |

**Encumbrance (Optional Rule).** If you carry weight in excess of 5 times your Strength score, you are encumbered, which means your Speed drops by 10 feet. If you carry weight in excess of 10 times your Strength score, up to your maximum carrying capacity, you are heavily encumbered, which means your Speed drops by 20 feet and you have Disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws that use Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution.

name: Objects
description:
When characters need to saw through ropes, shatter a window, or smash a vampire's coffin, the only hard and fast rule is this: given enough time and the right tools, characters can destroy any destructible object.

## Object Armor Class

| AC | Substance |
|----|----------|
| 11 | Cloth, paper, rope |
| 13 | Crystal, glass, ice |
| 15 | Wood |
| 17 | Stone |
| 19 | Iron, steel |
| 21 | Mithral |
| 23 | Adamantine |

## Object Hit Points

| Size | Fragile | Resilient |
|------|---------|----------|
| Tiny (bottle, lock) | 2 (1d4) | 5 (2d4) |
| Small (chest, lute) | 3 (1d6) | 10 (3d6) |
| Medium (barrel, chandelier) | 4 (1d8) | 18 (4d8) |
| Large (cart, dining table) | 5 (1d10) | 27 (5d10) |

**Huge and Gargantuan Objects.** Normal weapons are of little use against many Huge and Gargantuan objects, such as a colossal statue, towering column of stone, or massive boulder. That said, one torch can burn a Huge tapestry, and an earthquake spell can reduce a colossus to rubble. You can track a Huge or Gargantuan object's Hit Points if you like, or you can simply decide how long the object can withstand whatever weapon or force is acting against it.

name: Curses
description:
A curse is a magical burden that lasts for a specified time or until it is ended by some means. Curses can be removed by the Remove Curse and Greater Restoration spells or other magic that explicitly ends curses.

## Types of Curses

**Bestow Curse.** The simplest curses are created by the Bestow Curse spell. A curse that lasts for 1 minute equates to a level 3 spell, while one that lasts until dispelled equates to a level 9 spell.

**Cursed Creatures.** Some monsters are associated with curses, whether as part of their origins or due to their ability to spread curses—werewolves being a prime example.

**Cursed Magic Items.** Cursed magic items are created deliberately or originate as the result of supernatural events.

**Narrative Curses.** A curse might manifest during an adventure when a creature's violation of a taboo warrants supernatural punishment, such as breaking a vow, defiling a tomb, or murdering an innocent.

## Demonic Possession

Demonic Possession arises from the chaos and evil of the Abyss and commonly besets creatures that interact with demonic objects or linger in desecrated locations. A creature that becomes the target of Demonic Possession must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw or be possessed by a bodiless demonic entity. Whenever the possessed creature rolls a 1 on a D20 Test, the demonic entity takes control of the creature and determines the creature's behavior thereafter. At the end of each of the possessed creature's later turns, the creature makes a DC 15 Charisma saving throw, regaining control of itself on a success.

name: Cackle Fever
description:
Cheaply made potions and elixirs are sometimes tainted by Cackle Fever, which affects Humanoids only (gnomes are strangely immune). A creature suffers the following effects 1d4 days after infection.

**Fever.** The creature gains 1 Exhaustion level, which lasts until the contagion ends on the creature.

**Uncontrollable Laughter.** While the creature has the Exhaustion condition, the creature makes a DC 13 Constitution saving throw each time it takes damage other than Psychic damage. On a failed save, the creature takes 5 (1d10) Psychic damage and has the Incapacitated condition as it laughs uncontrollably. At the end of each of its turns, the creature repeats the save, ending the effect on itself on a success. After 1 minute, it succeeds automatically.

**Fighting the Contagion.** At the end of each Long Rest, an infected creature makes a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. After the creature succeeds on three of these saves, the contagion ends on it, and the creature is immune to Cackle Fever for 1 year.

**Spreading the Contagion.** Any Humanoid (other than a gnome) that starts its turn within a 10-foot Emanation originating from a creature infected with Cackle Fever must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or also become infected with the contagion.

name: Sewer Plague
description:
Fouled potions and alchemical waste can give rise to Sewer Plague, which incubates in sewers and refuse heaps and is sometimes transmitted by creatures that dwell in such areas, including otyughs and rats. A creature suffers the following effects 1d4 days after infection.

**Fatigue.** The creature gains 1 Exhaustion level.

**Weakness.** While the creature has any Exhaustion levels, it regains only half the normal number of Hit Points from spending Hit Point Dice.

**Restlessness.** While the creature has any Exhaustion levels, finishing a Long Rest neither restores lost Hit Points nor reduces the creature's Exhaustion level.

**Fighting the Contagion.** Daily at dawn, an infected creature makes a DC 11 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature gains 1 Exhaustion level as its fatigue worsens. On a successful save, the creature's Exhaustion level decreases by 1. If the creature's Exhaustion level is reduced to 0, the contagion ends on the creature.

name: Sight Rot
description:
Any Beast or Humanoid that drinks water tainted by Sight Rot must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or have the Blinded condition until the contagion ends.

**Fighting the Contagion.** Magic such as a Heal or Lesser Restoration spell ends the contagion immediately. A character who is proficient with an Herbalism Kit can use it to create one dose of nonmagical ointment, which takes 1 hour. When applied to the eyes of a creature suffering from Sight Rot, the ointment suppresses the contagion on that creature for 24 hours. If the contagion is suppressed in this way for a total of 72 hours (requiring three doses and applications of the ointment), the contagion ends on the creature.

**Spreading the Contagion.** Any Humanoid that makes skin contact with a creature infected with Sight Rot must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or also become infected with the contagion.

name: Poisons
description:
Poisons come in the following types:

- **Contact.** Contact poison can be smeared on an object and remains potent until it is touched or washed off. A creature that touches Contact poison with exposed skin suffers its effects.
- **Ingested.** A creature must swallow an entire dose of Ingested poison to suffer its effects. The dose can be delivered in food or a liquid.
- **Inhaled.** Inhaled poisons are powders or gases. A container of such poison can be thrown up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. The poison forms a 5-foot-radius Sphere that lasts for 1 minute in still air (a moderate wind disperses it in 4 rounds; a strong wind disperses it in 1 round). A creature that enters or starts its turn in the area is exposed to the poison and must make a saving throw against it.
- **Injury.** Injury poison can be applied to weapons, ammunition, trap components, and other objects that deal piercing or slashing damage. The poison remains potent for 1 minute or until delivered through a wound. A creature that takes piercing or slashing damage from an object coated with the poison is exposed to its effects.

## Poison List

| Poison | Type | Cost | DC |
|--------|------|------|----|
| Assassin's Blood | Ingested | 150 GP | 10 |
| Burnt Othur Fumes | Inhaled | 500 GP | 13 |
| Crawler Mucus | Contact | 200 GP | 13 |
| Essence of Ether | Inhaled | 300 GP | 15 |
| Malice | Inhaled | 250 GP | 15 |
| Midnight Tears | Ingested | 1,500 GP | 17 |
| Oil of Taggit | Contact | 400 GP | 13 |
| Pale Tincture | Ingested | 250 GP | 16 |
| Purple Worm Poison | Injury | 2,000 GP | 21 |
| Serpent Venom | Injury | 200 GP | 11 |
| Spider's Sting | Injury | 200 GP | 13 |
| Torpor | Ingested | 600 GP | 15 |
| Truth Serum | Ingested | 150 GP | 11 |
| Wyvern Poison | Injury | 1,200 GP | 14 |

name: Fear and Mental Stress
description:
Adventurers tend to be less susceptible to fear and mental stress than common folk. Certain creatures and game effects can terrify or fray the mind of even the most stalwart adventurer.

## Sample Fear DCs

| Example | DC |
|---------|----|
| When the characters open a sarcophagus, a harmless yet terrifying apparition appears | 10 |
| A character triggers a magical trap that creates an illusory manifestation of that character's worst fears | 15 |
| A portal to the Abyss opens, revealing a nightmarish realm of torment and slaughter | 20 |

## Additional Fear Effects

Beyond the standard Frightened condition, a GM might impose additional effects:
- The Frightened creature must take the Dash action on each of its turns and uses its movement to get farther away from the source of its fear.
- Attack rolls against the Frightened creature have Advantage.
- The Frightened creature can do only one of the following on each of its turns: move, take an action, or take a Bonus Action.

## Mental Stress

When a character is subjected to an effect that causes intense mental stress, Psychic damage is the best way to emulate that effect.

## Prolonged Effects

**Short-Term Effects.** The character has the Frightened, Incapacitated, or Stunned condition for 1d10 minutes. These effects can be suppressed with the Calm Emotions spell or removed by the Lesser Restoration spell.

**Long-Term Effects.** The character has Disadvantage on some or all ability checks for 1d10 x 10 hours. These effects can be suppressed with the Calm Emotions spell or removed by the Lesser Restoration spell.

**Indefinite Effects.** An indefinite effect is a long-term effect that lasts until removed by a Greater Restoration spell. It can be suppressed by a Calm Emotions spell.
